awd_titl_txt: Resilience, Reliability, and Externalities of Integrated Centralized and Distributed Water and Energy Systems: The Integrated Water-Energy Dynamic (iWED) Model
awd_abstract_narration:
1706143 (Mo). This project aims to identify trade-offs and synergies among centralized and distributed water and energy supply schemes and enhance understanding of water-energy interdependence and dynamics as demographics, climate, technologies, and policies change. To achieve this goal, a novel, integrated Water-Energy Dynamic (iWED) modeling framework will be created based on system dynamics (SD) theory coupling results from life cycle assessment, life cycle cost assessment, structural path analysis, and process-based climate and hydrologic models. A generic iWED model and decision making framework will first be developed on the regional scale. It will then be tested through two contrasting case studies: the Tampa Bay, FL region and the Great Boston area, MA region. 

In this project, all water and energy sources of a region will first be identified as critical resource components and simulated as stocks (time dependent cumulative levels of source availability). The inflows and outflows of each stock will be identified. A baseline water systems model will then be developed linking water sources, infrastructure capacity, and demand using existing climate and hydrologic models and mass balance equations. A similar energy systems model will also be established. The water systems model will then be linked with the energy systems model using outcomes of life cycle assessments, supplemented by structural path analysis. Changes in water and energy balance, interactions, and resilience will be examined when varied types and percentages of distributed water and energy systems are integrated into the existing network considering varied population and downscaled climate change scenarios. Based on the water and energy vulnerability and resilience results under varied decentralization scenarios, a life cycle cost model will be developed to evaluate the potential savings from centralized supply, capital and maintenance costs associated with distributed infrastructure, and potential incentive/disincentive policies that could support social justice and conservation goals with distributed water and energy systems. This work is target to generate new knowledge in 1) regional scale dynamic water-energy nexus quantifications over their entire life cycles; 2) the influences of the decentralization scale on water and energy availability and resiliency; 3) the influences of different and dynamic local contexts on the water-energy nexus under different water and energy supply schemes; and 4) the feasibility of policy and management strategies that simultaneously optimize characteristics of water and energy supply as well as promote social justice. This project will also result in the development of 1) a new integrated water, energy, fund availability and balance model - iWED, which can be generalized to any region of concern, 2) a life cycle cost inventory of different life cycle water and energy systems, and 3) dynamic policy and scenario analyses to inform integrated water and energy management and support decision making of future water and energy paradigm shift. The envisioned iWED model could easily be extended to support and advance the development of other pertinent research fields such as understanding the interactions among other critical resources (e.g., the food-water-energy nexus), smart and net-zero communities, urban metabolism, and industrial symbiosis. This project will also result in development of a new open-sourced learning module, which can be integrated into undergraduate and graduate level systems analysis courses, and an educational role-play game that can be used to promote systems thinking and improve understanding of the water-energy nexus.

por.por_cntn:
Centralized water and energy systems are usually inextricably intertwined – without energy, water cannot be provided and without water, energy cannot be supplied. This “water-energy nexus” increases the vulnerability of both water and energy supplies and intensify stress and shortage of both resources. This project aims to identify the trade-offs and synergies among centralized and decentralized water and energy supply schemes and enhance understandings of water-energy interdependence and dynamics as demographics, climate, technologies, and policies change. To achieve this, numerical models were developed to capture the temporal and spatial water-energy interactions considering both existing centralized water and energy services as well as future residential adoption of decentralized water (rainwater harvesting and greywater recycling systems) and energy (solar photovoltaic (PV)) systems. Using Boston, MA as a testbed, we found only less 12% of the residential buildings can achieve cost savings by installing rainwater harvesting systems. These systems will increase life cycle energy use by about 400 MJ/year. All buildings can achieve cost savings by installing greywater recycling systems, and these systems will result in a life cycle energy saving of about 600 MJ/year. Boston has a significant proportion of households belonging to early adopters, suggesting support from the public sector to help initialize the adoption of decentralized water systems will accelerate the diffusion. Spatially, the central Boston area has a strong presence of early adopters and is generally good for installing decentralized water systems from both cost and energy perspectives. Combined with the fact that this area is also one of the oldest areas in Boston with relatively low income, incentives might be provided to foster the integration of decentralized water systems with infrastructure renovation projects to promote community renaissance. Temporally, climate change is likely to increase the overall energy use by the urban water services. When climate change is combined with decentralization, life cycle energy is projected to increase by 0.9% and 2.3% towards the end of the century if rainwater harvesting and greywater recycling systems are installed in all buildings that can yield positive cost savings, respectively. From an energy system perspective, maximizing the selling or use of solar energy during the on-peak hours through battery installation and control can achieve the highest life cycle water and cost saving under the time-of-use (TOU) rate design. There is a tradeoff between water savings and carbon emission reductions as the New England grid has a higher carbon emission factor during the on-peak hours, compared to the mid-peak hours. This is because of a higher grid contribution of hydropower instead of natural gas during the on-peak hours. The increase in battery charging cycles as a result of its control strategy may also result in energy losses that outweigh the benefit of installing a battery. Spatially, a 100% residential adoption of decentralized solar PV systems meets about 39% of residential electricity demand and reduce about 5,000 m3 of life cycle water use per building. The fastest increase in life cycle water saving is seen when the top 16.6% of buildings with the largest roof sizes install solar PV systems. A higher adoption rate can lead to a steeper ramp-up curve in the residential grid demand, especially during winter months, due to a high load reduction during mid-peak hours, but relatively low load reductions during on- and off-peak hours. This indicates the significance of implementing seasonal TOU rate designs to match the local demand with PV generation. While adoption rate will influence the grid mix to an extent, we found such an influence has limited effect on the electricity price. Similar as decentralized water systems, early adopters of decentralized energy systems tend to reside in the relatively low-income central Boston area. Infrastructure improvement projects that include the installation of decentralized energy systems can help promote social equity in the area.
